On 8/22/06, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
>
> C=C3=A9dric=
 Beust =E2=99=94 wrote:
>
> > So you're recommending 100% code coverage?
> =
>
>
> Yes.


That's not very realistic, is it?

In reality, we need to make=
 compromises all the time and decide what part of
our code we're not going =
to write tests for, so in effect, there *is* code
that is too simple to be =
tested.

More specifically in this article, I'm recommending that when you
=
> find a bug, you write a test for it first, even if the fix is obvious.
> =
The class in question had 100% code coverage before the bug was noticed.
> =
  100% code coverage is practically a necessary but not sufficient
> condit=
ion for bug free code.


100% code coverage is not just impossible to obtai=
n and maintain, it's also
deceptive and can make you think you are exercisi=
ng your code in all
possible ways.  Which is, of course, never true.

If I =
have to choose between bumping my code coverage from 90% to 91% and
writing=
 a test that will exercise a documented feature, I will pick the
latter any=
 day.

-- 
C=C3=A9dric
http://testng.org
